member.name: T:Photon.SocketServer.Mmo.InterestArea
member.summary:
Provides a mechanism to subscribe items and regions in a world.
Interest areas have
an that is unique per
a
a subscribe threshold ()
an unsubscribe threshold ()
The InterestArea subscribes to regions that overlap with the inner view radius.
Whenever an moves into a new it sends an into the region. Interest areas that receive this message automatically subscribe to the (unless AutoSubscribeItem returns false).
If the interest area moves and subscribes to a new it sends a into the region. Receiving items answer with an .
The interest area analyzes one every few seconds from each subscribed item and then checks if the item moved out of the interest areas outer view radius. The check interval is configured with .
Interest areas can be attached to an . Once an interest area is attached it moves wherever the item by receiving all position updates from the items . Per default interest areas do not auto subscribe their (see AutoSubscribeItem).

member.name: T:Photon.SocketServer.Mmo.Item
member.summary:
Represents an entity in a world. Items are event publisher and the counterpart to InterestAreas.
Items have
a ,
a per type unique ,
a ,
with a revision number
and 3 different MessageChannels:
: for interest areas.
: Position updates for attached and subscribed interest areas. Attached interest areas move to the same position and subscribed interest areas unsubscribe when the item leaves the outer threshold (one position update is analyzed every few seconds).
: Subscribed interest areas are informed when the item is disposed in order to unsubscribe.
member.remarks: Item accessing operations are required to be invoked on the item's .

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadArray(System.Object@)
member.summary: Reads an array from the underling stream.
member.remarks: For associative arrays, data is in name/value pairs, similar to how objects are encoded (type 2). If the integer-data was zero, then the name/value pairs are terminated by a single-null string (that is simply a 1). If the integer-data was 1, then the name/value pairs are terminated by a single-null value string as well, but the null-value string will also have a final value. This second case occurs when the associative array has defined a key that is either 0 or \\ (empty string). If both 0 and \\ are set in the array then the first name/value pair sent will have a null string for the key and the final name/value pair sent will also have a null string for a key. (Im not sure if there is any other way to get a null string key.) The zero value seems to be always the one sent first in case of the two null strings.

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadByteArray
member.summary: Reads a byte array from a binary reader.
member.remarks: ActionScript 3.0 introduces a new type to hold an Array of bytes, namely ByteArray. AMF 3 serializes this type using a variable length encoding 29-bit integer for the byte-length prefix followed by the raw bytes of the ByteArray. ByteArray instances can be sent as a reference to a previously occurring ByteArray instance by using an index to the implicit object reference table.
member.returns: A byte array containing data read from the underlying stream.

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadInlineArray(System.Int32,System.Object@)
member.summary: Reads an inline array from the underling stream
member.returns: A array object read from the current stream.

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadInlineDynamicObject(System.Object@)
member.remarks: If there is a class-def reference there are no property names and the number of values is equal to the number of properties in the class-def.

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadInteger
member.summary: Reads the next 1-4 bytes (variable bit length) from the binary stream and converts the result to an unsigned integer.
member.remarks: AMF 3 represents smaller integers with fewer bytes using the most significant bit of each byte. The worst case uses 32-bits to represent a 29-bit number, which is what we would have done with no compression. To save space it is an integer that can be 1-4 bytes long. The first bit of the first three bytes determine if the next byte is included (1) in this integer-data or not (0). The last byte, if present, is read completely (8 bits). The first bits are then removed from the first three bytes and the remaining bits concatenated to form a big-endian integer. The integer is negative if it is the full 29 bits long and the first bit is set (1). This uses Two's complement notation and is therefore identical to normal signed integer behaviour. - 0x00000000 - 0x0000007F : 0xxxxxxx - 0x00000080 - 0x00003FFF : 1xxxxxxx 0xxxxxxx - 0x00004000 - 0x001FFFFF : 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx 0xxxxxxx - 0x00200000 - 0x3FFFFFFF : 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx 1xxxxxxx xxxxxxxx - 0x40000000 - 0xFFFFFFFF : throw range exception

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadObject(System.Object@)
member.summary: Reads an object from the underling stream.

member.name: M:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Protocols.Amf3.Amf3Reader.ReadString(System.String@)
member.summary: Read and deserialize a string Strings can be sent as a reference to a previously occurring String by using an index to the implicit string reference table. Strings are encoding using UTF-8 - however the header may either describe a string literal or a string reference. - string = 0x06 string-data - string-data = integer-data [ modified-utf-8 ] - modified-utf-8 = *OCTET

member.name: P:Photon.SocketServer.Rpc.Peer.CurrentOperationHandler
member.summary:
Gets the current . and calls the .
The operation handler can be changed with SetCurrentOperationHandler. This allows a different behavior when a peer's state changes: For instance, after a login operation many operations will no longer have to return an error and can actually do something. Using different IOperationHandlers is much more elegant than checking a "isLoggedIn" variable with every request.
